bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert Usher, November 1, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Usher a reprint of his yellow fever article and requests references on yellow fever in New Orleans.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert Usher, November 1, 1941
div1.opener:
November 1, 1941
Mr. Robert Usher
Librarian, Tulane University Library
New Orleans, Louisiana
My dear Mr. Usher:
div1.p:
I have had such a pleasant letter from
Mr. Alfred D. Danziger of New Orleans, to whom I mentioned
my interest in the history of yellow fever, especially in
New Orleans. Most graciously he has sent me already a list
of books which he believed might interest me, and I believe
he has mentioned to you this interest of mine. Permit me
to send you by separate post a little article of mine which
just appeared in the current issue of Hygeia. Whatever in-
formation you can give me I should appreciate greatly as I
plan to write eventually a monograph on the subject.

I do not, however, want you to go to great
trouble, but I would like to have some references that
illustrate the human rather than the scientific side of
the yellow fever epidemics in New Orleans.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
